comments:
Introduction to Biology: The Molecular Biology of Life is an intensive
introductory lecture course covering the cell, molecular biology, biochemistry, and the
genetics of animals, bacteria, and viruses. This course is comparable to Biology 101 but
places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches,
especially with regards to the mechanistic basis of human disease.
Nearly every student agreed that this class was “interesting” with a good range
and depth of topics. Students overall reported learning a lot from this “informative” class,
saying that it was a “very good introduction to biology.” Some students like having four
different professors because they liked each professor’s perspective, while others thought
that the course suffered from a lack of consistency and structure, making it hard to get to
know and get used to a professor. Recitation was held with the entire class, but several
students found this to be “ineffective.” Students were also not very complimentary of the
textbook/readings and found lectures to be more useful for exams.
Students generally liked Professor Goulian, describing him as “very good,”
“clear,” and noting that his lectures “followed nicely with the textbook.”
This course fulfills the Living World Sector. Prerequisites include solid high
school biology and strong high school chemistry or CHEM 101 taken concurrently. It is
also required that BIOL 123 is taken concurrently. Many students reported that this was
among the most—if not the most—challenging courses they had taken at Penn. They
described the course as fast-paced, “intense” and “competitive,” describing exams as
“rough” and “very challenging.” While a few thought the course was “fairly evaluated,”
more students criticized the difficulty of the scale, saying it was “not very generous.”
Students appreciated being allowed to drop a midterm. Exams emphasized applying
concepts rather than memory and “regurgitation” of information. In summary: “this
course is interesting and challenging, but the grading is so difficult that I would not
recommend this course unless you have to take it.” This course was not recommended to
first semester freshmen.

This introductory lecture and laboratory course emphasizes mechanistic
approaches to the understanding of modern biology. The course considers how molecular
methods and principles contribute to the understanding of biochemistry, cell biology and
genetics, in the context of evolutionary, developmental and physiological processes. In
addition to studying the current status of biomedical knowledge, every effort is made to
provide an understanding of how biological systems work, and the methods of biological
research. This course addresses not just the WHAT, but also the HOW and (where
possible) the WHY. Contemporary methods encompassing such areas as applied
biotechnology, genomics, molecular medicine, and the biology of disease are integral
components of the course. Topics to be covered include: protein structure; enzymes;
lipids and membranes; polysaccharides and cell walls; membrane proteins; primary and
secondary transporters; cellular respiration; ion channels; receptors and signal
transduction; protein and vesicular traffic; the cytoskeleton, cell cycle and cell division;
DNA replication and repair; transcription, translation and mutations; model organisms
and genomics; gene regulation; Mendelian and population genetics.
Students said the course material was “interesting.” However, many found the
course to be too technical. The course pushes students to think about biological
processes rather than simply regurgitate information. One student said “This course
provided an in depth introduction to essential concepts of molecular biology. It ties topics
together in a new way that is less textbook intensive, focusing on the research aspect and
real world applications of the concepts learned. The guest lectures were great in applying
concepts learned to real world situations.” Many students found the course to be very
informational, however, said that the class lacked a focused direction. Students describe
the course as “fast paced.” Overall students found that the course required much
dedication to understand the material, but the knowledge gained from the course was
priceless for those interested in the sciences.
Professor Rea was said to be the standout lecturer among the four professors in
this course. He was said to be passionate about teaching students. In addition, he always
made himself readily available to students.
This course fulfills the Living World Sector requirement. The prerequisites
include solid high school biology and strong high school chemistry or CHEM 101 taken
concurrently. BIOL 121 and 123 must be taken concurrently. Biology Majors and Pre-
Medical students should take either BIOL 101 or 121. BIOL 121 is the companion course
to BIOL 124 and may be taken before or after BIOL 124. Many students said this course
was “extremely difficult.” They found that the material covered in the class did not
prepare students adequately for the exam questions. They said that the curve was
“terrible.” Many of the students who take this course are fulfilling their pre-med
requirements; the composition of this course breeds a competitive atmosphere.

This introductory lecture course emphasizes mechanistic approaches to the
understanding of modern biology. Molecular methods and principles contribute to our
understanding of biochemistry, cell biology and genetics, in the context of evolutionary,
developmental and physiological processes. In addition to studying the current status of
biomedical knowledge, every effort is made to provide an understanding of how
biological systems work, and the methods of biological research. Not just the WHAT,
but also the HOW and (where possible) the WHY are addressed. Contemporary methods
encompassing such areas as applied biotechnology, genomics, molecular medicine, and
the biology of disease are integral components of the course. Topics to be covered
include: protein structure; enzymes; lipids and membranes; polysaccharides and cell
walls; membrane proteins; membrane transport; cellular respiration; ion channels;
receptors and signal transduction; protein and vesicular traffic; the cytoskeleton, cell
cycle and cell division; DNA replication and repair; transcription, translation and
mutations; model organisms and genomics; gene regulation; Mendelian and population
genetics.
Many students felt that the course was “interesting,” but was taught at too fast of a
pace. Overall, they felt that having four different professors made learning more difficult
because they needed to adjust to different teaching styles and paces. This course was
categorized as “demanding and intensive,” and students felt that the questions that
appeared on the exam didn’t always correlate to what was learned in class.
The majority of students felt that Professor Brisson’s lectures were not very
comprehensive. Some said that he had “good intentions,” but is a “poor communicator”
of the material.
Most of the students felt that this course was extremely difficult, and some
recommended that it was not a good course for first semester freshmen. The grades they
received in the course were lower than what they expected. Mainly, they recommended
this course to premedical students. Overall, the students felt that the readings in the book
were “worthless.” This class fulfills the living world sector.

This is an intensive introductory lecture course covering the cell, molecular
biology, biochemistry, and the genetics of animals, bacteria, and viruses. This course is
comparable to Biology 101, but places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and
experimental approaches. Particular attention is given to the ways in which modern cell
biological and molecular genetic methods contribute to our understanding of evolutionary
processes, the mechanistic basis of human disease, and recent biotechnological
innovations.
Students found this class to be very “interesting” but also at times “intense.”
Students reported that the amount of information was at times “overwhelming,”
especially when compared to AP Biology. Many students mentioned that the course goes
beyond wrote memorization and into the domain of real world application.
Students found it difficult to follow the professors in lecture, especially since
there were four of them. It was often difficult to get in contact with professors outside of
the classroom and one student mentioned having to go to “four review sessions” in order
to get all the material for the final. Students often mentioned that the book was not
helpful and that most of the material comes from the lecture slides that are posted online.
Most students found this class to be extremely difficult. Many expressed
difficulty in answering questions on the exams and that they seemed to be drawn out of
no-where. Students mentioned that this class is intended for majors. Students expressed
that many of the questions on the test involved application of material and not simply
memorization.
